official-title.#text: To prioritize and redirect NOAA resources to a focused program of investment on near-term, affordable, and attainable advances in observational, computing, and modeling capabilities to deliver substantial improvement in weather forecasting and prediction of high impact weather events, such as tornadoes and hurricanes, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Science, Space, and Technology

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

cosponsor.#text: Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas

action-desc.#text: Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed

action-desc.#text: Reported with an amendment, committed to the Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union, and ordered to be printed

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: critical mission to provide science, service, and stewardship, the

shall prioritize weather-related activities, including the provision of weather data, forecasts, and warnings for the protection of life and property and the enhancement of the national economy, in all relevant line offices.

text.#text: In accordance with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall conduct a program to develop improved understanding of and forecast capabilities for atmospheric events and their impacts, placing priority on developing more accurate, timely, and effective warnings and forecasts of high impact weather events that endanger life and property.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall focus on the following activities:

text.#text: The program described in
Improving the fundamental understanding of weather consistent with

internal-xref.#tail: , including boundary layer and other atmospheric processes.

text.#text: Improving the understanding of how the public receives, interprets, and responds to warnings and forecasts of high impact weather events that endanger life and property.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and other appropriate agencies and entities, including the American weather industry and academic partners, related to—

text.#text: Research and development, and transfer of knowledge, technologies, and applications to the

advanced radar, radar networking technologies, and other ground-based technologies, including those emphasizing rapid, fine-scale sensing of the boundary layer and the use of innovative, dual-polarization, phased-array technologies;
aerial weather observing systems;
high performance computing and information technology networks;
advanced numerical weather prediction systems and forecasting tools and techniques that improve the forecasting of timing, track, intensity, and severity of high impact weather, including through—
the development of more effective mesoscale models;
more effective use of existing, and the development of new, regional and national cloud-resolving models;
enhanced global models; and
integrated assessment models;
quantitative assessment tools for measuring the value of data and observing systems, including OSSEs (as described in

atmospheric chemistry and interactions essential to accurately characterizing atmospheric composition and predicting meteorological processes, including cloud microphysical, precipitation, and atmospheric electrification processes, to more effectively understand their role in severe weather; and
additional sources of weather data and information, including commercial observing systems.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and in cooperation with the American weather industry and academic partners, to ensure continuous development and transition of the latest scientific and technological advances into

text.#text: A technology transfer initiative, carried out jointly and in coordination with the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall collaborate with and support the non-Federal weather research community, which includes institutions of higher education, private entities, and nongovernmental organizations, by making funds available through competitive grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

text.#text: In carrying out the program under this section, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that not less than 30 percent of the funds authorized for research and development at
by this Act should be made available for this purpose.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

text.#text: It is the sense of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: budget request, a description of current and planned activities under this section.

text.#text: The

header.#text: Tornado warning improvement and extension program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in collaboration with the American weather industry and academic partners, shall establish a tornado warning improvement and extension program.

text.#text: The

The goal of such program shall be to reduce the loss of life and economic losses from tornadoes through the development and extension of accurate, effective, and timely tornado forecasts, predictions, and warnings, including the prediction of tornadoes beyond one hour in advance.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall develop a program plan that details the specific research, development, and technology transfer activities, as well as corresponding resources and timelines, necessary to achieve the program goal.

text.#text: Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a proposed budget corresponding to the activities identified in the plan.

text.#text: Following completion of the plan, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in collaboration with the American weather industry and academic partners, shall establish a hurricane warning improvement program.

text.#text: The
The goal of such program shall be to develop and extend accurate hurricane forecasts and warnings in order to reduce loss of life, injury, and damage to the economy.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , shall develop a program plan that details the specific research, development, and technology transfer activities, as well as corresponding resources and timelines, necessary to achieve the program goal.

text.#text: In support of the requirements of
may include assessments of the impact of observing capabilities on—
global weather prediction;
hurricane track and intensity forecasting;
tornado warning lead times and accuracy; and
prediction of mid-latitude severe local storm outbreaks; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , other Federal agencies, the American weather industry, and academic partners.

text.#text: shall be conducted in cooperation with other appropriate entities within
OSSEs shall quantitatively—
determine the potential impact of proposed space-based, suborbital, and in situ observing systems on analyses and forecasts;
evaluate and compare observing system design options; and
assess the relative capabilities and costs of various observing systems and combinations of observing systems in providing data necessary to protect life and property.
OSSEs—

shall be conducted prior to the acquisition of major Government-owned or Government-leased operational observing systems, including polar-orbiting and geostationary satellite systems, with a lifecycle cost of more than $500,000,000; and
shall be conducted prior to the purchase of any major new commercially provided data with a lifecycle cost of more than $500,000,000.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall complete OSSEs to assess the value of data from both Global Positioning System radio occultation and a geostationary hyperspectral sounder global constellation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

text.#text: Not later than June 30, 2014, the

Upon completion of all OSSEs, results shall be publicly released and accompanied by an assessment of related private and public sector weather data sourcing options, including their availability, affordability, and cost effectiveness. Such assessments shall be developed in accordance with

text.#text: Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter, the NOAA Chief Information Officer, in coordination with the
aggressively pursue the newest, fastest, and most cost effective high performance computing technologies in support of its weather prediction mission;
ensure a balance between the research requirements to develop the next generation of regional and global models and its highly reliable operational models;

take advantage of advanced development concepts to, as appropriate, make its next generation weather prediction models available in beta-test mode to its operational forecasters, the American weather industry, and its partners in academic and government research;
identify opportunities to reallocate existing advanced computing resources from lower priority uses to improve advanced research and operational weather prediction; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: for immediate improvement in forecasting and experimentation.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following:

text.#text: This prohibition shall not extend to—
the purchase of weather data through contracts with commercial providers; or
the placement of weather satellite instruments on cohosted government or private payloads.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a strategy to enable the procurement of quality commercial weather data. The strategy shall assess the range of commercial opportunities, including public-private partnerships, for obtaining both surface-based and space-based weather observations. The strategy shall include the cost effectiveness of these opportunities, as well as provide a plan for procuring data from these nongovernmental sources, as appropriate.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate

text.#text: Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the
The strategy shall include—
an analysis of financial or other benefits to, and risks associated with, acquiring commercial weather data or services, including through multiyear acquisition approaches;
an identification of methods to address planning, programming, budgeting, and execution challenges to such approaches, including—
how standards will be set to ensure that data is reliable and effective;
how data may be acquired from commercial experimental or innovative techniques and then evaluated for integration into operational use;
how to guarantee public access to all forecast-critical data to ensure that the American weather industry and the public continue to have access to information critical to their work; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , methods to address potential termination liability or cancellation costs associated with weather data or service contracts; and

text.#text: in accordance with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to facilitate effective and efficient implementation of such strategy.

text.#text: an identification of any changes needed in the requirements development and approval processes of the

text.#text: The
The Advisory Committee shall be composed of at least 12 members, with the chair of the Advisory Committee chosen from among the members.

identify and prioritize top forecast needs and coordinate those needs against budget requests and program initiatives across participating offices and agencies; and

The Federal Coordinator for Meteorology shall serve as a co-chair of this panel.
